explosives.rationale: Containing no chemical groups with explosive properties

flammable_gases.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

oxidizing_gases.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

gases_under_pressure.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

flammable_liquids.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

flammable_solids.rationale: Classified as "flammable" according to ICSC (2000). Classified into Division 6.1 (UN#1674) (UN Recommendations on the Transport of Dangerous Goods)

self_reactive_substances.rationale: Containing no chemical groups with explosive or self-reactive properties

pyrophoric_liquids.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

pyrophoric_solids.rationale: Classified into Division 6.1 (UN#1674) (UN Recommendations on the Transport of Dangerous Goods)

self_heating_substances.rationale: Classified into Division 6.1 (UN#1674) (UN Recommendations on the Transport of Dangerous Goods)

substances_mixtures_emit_flammable_gas_i.hazard_name: Substances and mixtures which, in contact with water, emit flammable gases

oxidizing_liquids.rationale: Classified as "solid" according to GHS definition

oxidizing_solids.rationale: No data available, though being organic compounds containing oxygen bound to carbon and hydrogen. Classified into Division 6.1 by UN Recommendations on the Transport of Dangerous Goods (UN#1674)

corrosive_to_metals.rationale: Test methods applicable to solid substances are not available

acute_toxicity_oral.rationale: Based on the rat LD50 (oral route) value of 22mg/kg representing the lower of the two testing data, 41mg/kg (RTECS (2005)) and 22mg/kg (HSDB (2005)).

acute_toxicity_inhalation_gas.rationale: Due to the fact that the substance is "solid" according to the GHS definition and inhalation of its gas is not expected.

skin_corrosion_irritation.rationale: Based on the evidence of "reddening, pain, blurred vision and severe deep burn" (ICSC (J) (2005)).

serious_eye_damage_irritation.rationale: Based on the evidence of "reddening, pain, blurred vision and severe deep burn" (ICSC (J) (2005)).

germ_cell_mutagenicity.hazard_statement: May cause an allergic skin reaction
germ_cell_mutagenicity.rationale: Based on the description in DFGOT vol.15 (2001) of the human health effects: "the substance induced skin sensitization." Also due to the fact that mercury is classified as "skin sensitization" by the ad hoc committee of the Japanese Society of Occupational Allergy, and "Skin Sensitizing Substance: Group 1" by the Japan Society for Occupational Health, though these classifications are not specifying mercury phenyl acetate per se.* * There is a provision to the effect that "the category refers to the substance concerned and its compounds, but does not identify all substances causing respiratory/skin sensitization.

carcinogenicity.rationale: Based on positive data on somatic cell mutagenicity tests in vivo and the absence of data on germ cell genotoxicity in vivo. The positive results (as mercury compounds) are also available in multi-generation mutagenicity tests and germ cell mutagenicity tests in vivo, but not used for effects assessment.

systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.hazard_statement: Suspected of damaging fertility or the unborn child
systemic_toxicity_single_exposure.rationale: Based on the evidence of central nervous/muscle system abnormality in offspring, described in RTECS (2006) (though no data are available on maternal toxicity).

systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Single exposure
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.hazard_statement: May cause damage to organs (kidney, respiratory system)
systemic_toxicity_repeat_exposure.rationale: Based on the evidence reported in ICSC (J) 2000: "corrosive to the respiratory tract; corrosion following oral ingestion; adversely affects the kidney; may lead to renal failure. These effects may be delayed." Classified as priority 2 by ICSC (J).

aspiration_hazard.hazard_name: Specific target organ toxicity - Repeated exposure
aspiration_hazard.classification: Category 1 (nervous system, digestive system, respiratory system, kidney)
aspiration_hazard.hazard_statement: Cause damage to organs through prolonged or repeated exposure (nervous system, digestive system, respiratory system, kidney)
aspiration_hazard.rationale: Based on the human evidence including "severe neurotoxicity...swelling of the mouth, reddening and malacia of the gingiva, coloring of gingiva (blue line), decayed tooth, buccopharyngeal swelling" and "dyspnea, respiratory depression, breathing disturbed by viscous liquid...purulent pneumonia noted at necropsy" following inhalation exposure (ATSDR (1999)), and the evidence from animal studies including "kidney damage" following oral exposure (IRIS (2002)). The effects on the mouth and gingiva observed in humans were not caused by direct irritation. The effects on experimental animals were observed at dosing levels within the guidance value ranges for Category 1.

acute_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: Classification not possible due to lack of data

chronic_aquatic_toxicity.rationale: Classification not possible due to lack of data
